prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To maximize the continuum sensitivity, we use Time Division Mode that gives an effective instantaneous frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz.

The source size is expected to be compact, <~0".5 including the lensing source distortion (Capak et al. 2015, Ishigaki et al. 2015). Because we do not want to loose the sensitivity by the high resolution observations, we request observations with the angular resolution of >=0".5. On the other hand, a large beam would increase the uncertainties from the cofusion of the neighboring objects. Thus, we prefer the angular resolution of ~0".6-0".9. The acceptable angular resolution is ~0".5-1".5. Our first- and second-choice configuratoins are C36-2 and C36-1, respectively.

We observe HFF1C-Y5 and HFF1C-Y6 in one pointing. These sources are located at the positions 5".5 apart from the pointing center, where the primary beam has sensitivities of ~=86%. The required integration time is calculated with the primary-beam correction and the fainter source of HFF1C-Y6 whose expected 1.1mm flux is 0.13 mJy. We expect to reach 0.13mJy at the ~7 sigma level at the positions of HFF1C-Y5 and HFF1C-Y6.

We perform our observations at the 271 GHz band that is advantageous for detecting the redshifted dust emission peaked at ~1mm with a good sensitivity from the ground. This frequency increases the chance of detections. Here, we carefully choose the high transmission frequency of 271 GHz.
To maximize the continuum sensitivity, we use Time Division Mode that gives an effective instantenous frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz.

The source size is expected to be compact, <~0".5 including the lensing source distortion (Capak et al. 2015, Ishigaki et al. 2015). Because we do not want to loose the sensitivity by the high resolution observations, we request observations with the angular resolution of >=0".5. On the other hand, a large beam would increase the uncertainties from the confusion of the neighboring objects. Thus, we prefer the angular resolution of ~0".6-0".9. The acceptable angular resolution is ~0".5-1".5. Our first- and second-choice configurations are C36-2 and C36-1, respectively.
We aim to accomplish the S/N ratio of 10 for the secure detection, if the source has the expected 1.1mm flux.

The acceptable angular resolution is ~0".5-1".5. Our first- and second-choice configurations are C36-2 and C36-1, respectively.
We aim to accomplish the S/N ratio of ~7 for the reasonably secure detection, if the source has the expected 1.1mm flux.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent ALMA observations have detected the strong dust continuum in A1689-zD1, a lensed LBG at z=7.5. Theoretical studies indicate that the dust mass of A1689-zD1, ~4x10^7 Mo, is too great to be produced at such an early cosmic epoch in conventional dust grain growth scenarios, and thus a new mechanism of efficient growth over a very short accretion time scale may be required. Here we propose deep Band 6 observations to detect the dust continua of 7 red LBGs at z~7-8 that are the best mm-bright dusty LBG candidates among our large sample of 1012 LBGs at z~6.5-9 drawn from most of the major Hubble survey data, available to date. Our goals are to evaluate how common dusty LBGs at z~7-8 are, as the first step in statistical studies, and to search for the earliest dusty LBGs to provide improved constraints on the efficiency of the early dust production. Because two of our targets reside within the highest overdensity region of z~8 LBGs so far identified, our program will also investigate whether dust grain growth is an environmentally-dependent process.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
